components.name: Sol
components.description: Our home star, a middle-aged yellow dwarf that has been shining for 4.6 billion years. It makes up 99.86% of the Solar System's mass and provides the energy that sustains life on Earth. Sol is currently in the main sequence phase of its life cycle and will continue fusing hydrogen for another 5 billion years before evolving into a red giant.

components.name: Alpha Centauri A
components.description: The primary star of the Alpha Centauri system and one of the brightest stars visible from Earth. This yellow dwarf is slightly larger and more luminous than the Sun, with similar spectral characteristics. Rigil Kentaurus forms a tight binary with its K-type companion, completing an orbit every 79.9 years. The star's stable output and Sun-like properties make it a prime candidate for hosting potentially habitable planets.
components.alternate_names: Rigil Kentaurus, Rigil Kent, α Centauri A, HD 128620, HR 5459

components.name: Alpha Centauri B
components.description: The secondary component of the Alpha Centauri binary pair, this orange dwarf star is slightly smaller and cooler than the Sun. Despite being dimmer than its companion, Toliman is still bright enough to be visible to the naked eye as part of the combined Alpha Centauri system. Its K-type spectrum gives it a distinct orange hue, and it orbits Alpha Centauri A at distances ranging from 11 to 36 AU.
components.alternate_names: Toliman, α Centauri B, HD 128621, HR 5460

components.name: Proxima Centauri
components.description: The closest individual star to Earth, this tiny red dwarf is too faint to see without a telescope despite its proximity. Proxima orbits the Alpha Centauri AB binary pair at roughly 13,000 AU (about 0.21 light-years), taking approximately 550,000 years to complete one orbit. It hosts at least two confirmed exoplanets, including Proxima Centauri b, a potentially habitable world discovered in 2016. As a flare star, Proxima experiences dramatic brightness increases that could impact any planetary atmospheres.
components.alternate_names: Proxima Centauri, Alpha Centauri C, Gliese 551, V645 Centauri

components.name: Barnard's Star
components.description: The fastest-moving star in the night sky, this ancient red dwarf travels across the sky at an incredible 10.3 arcseconds per year. Despite being the fourth-closest star to Earth, it's too faint to see without a telescope. This single star is estimated to be 7-12 billion years old, making it one of the oldest stars in our galactic neighborhood. Its high proper motion was first measured by Edward Emerson Barnard in 1916.

components.name: Luhman 16A
components.description: The primary component of the Luhman 16 brown dwarf binary system. This L-type brown dwarf is one of the closest substellar objects to Earth, yet remained undiscovered until 2013 due to its extremely low luminosity. At just 34 Jupiter masses, it's too small to sustain hydrogen fusion, making it more like a massive planet than a true star. Its dull red color and cool temperature of 1,300K make it visible only in infrared light.

components.name: Luhman 16B
components.description: The secondary component of the Luhman 16 brown dwarf binary, this T-type brown dwarf is even cooler and dimmer than its companion. At just 28 Jupiter masses, it represents the boundary between the largest planets and the smallest stars. Its magenta color and temperature of 1,200K make it one of the coldest known brown dwarfs. The pair orbit each other every 27 years at a distance of about 3 AU.

components.name: Sirius A
components.alternate_names: Alpha Canis Majoris, Dog Star, HD 48915, HR 2491

components.name: Sirius B
components.alternate_names: Alpha Canis Majoris B, HD 48915B, WD 0642-166

components.name: Epsilon Eridani
components.alternate_names: Ran, ε Eridani, 18 Eridani, HD 22049, Gliese 144

components.name: Procyon A
components.star_type: F-type main sequence star transitioning to subgiant
components.alternate_names: Alpha Canis Minoris, HD 61421, HIP 37279, Gliese 280A

components.name: Procyon B
components.alternate_names: Alpha Canis Minoris B, HD 61421B, Gliese 280B

components.name: 61 Cygni A
components.alternate_names: HD 201091, HIP 104214, Gliese 820 A, Bessel's Star

components.name: Epsilon Indi Bb
components.star_type: Brown dwarf (late T-type methane brown dwarf)
